sen.e: However, Masakazu was born, after the Asai clan was annihilated by Nobunaga ODA, when Masatsugu was given patronage of Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, who was the lord of the Nagahama-jo Castle (Omi Province) and he was serving Hideyoshi's younger brother, Hidenaga TOYOTOMI.

sen.e: Other than the work for the Imperial Court, he is known to have worked on the interior of Edo-jo Castle and the construction of Tokai-ji Temple in Shinagawa (a family temple and villa for the Tokugawa family in Shinagawa Ward), Minakuchi-jo Castle to accommodate the seii taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians") on his way to Kyoto (Minakuchimachi, Koga City, Shiga Prefecture), Iba Ochaya (rest house) (Notogawa-cho, Higashiomi City, Shiga Prefecture), and the ochaya within Osaka-jo Castle grounds.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました

sen.j: また京都の寺では、将軍の側近者崇伝長老の住坊である南禅寺金地院内東照宮や御祈祷殿（方丈）側の富貴の間、茶室および庭園、同寺本坊の方丈庭園など、準公儀の作事に参画している。
sen.e: With respect to temples in Kyoto, he was involved in construction works related to some extent to the shogunate such as Toshogu in Konchi-in subtemple of the Nanzen-ji Temple, which was the priests lodge for Suden Choro, who was a close advisor of the shogun, fukinoma, tea house and garden on the Gokito-den (Hall for prayer) (hojo (an abbot's chamber)) side, and hojo teien (garden) of the honbo (a priest's main living quarter) of the temple.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外措置
sen.e: In Kyoto, he was involved in construction work that related in some way to the shogunate, such as Toshogu (in Konchi-in subtemple of the Nanzen-ji Temple), a lodge for Suden Choro, a priest who was a close advisor of the shogun, and in the same temple, a hall, tea house and garden on the hojo (abbot's chamber) side of Gokito-den (Hall for prayer) and the hojo teien (garden) of the honbo (priests' main living quarters).
sen.cmt: Natural English
sen.e: Among the temples in Kyoto, he participated in semi-official construction work such as Toshogu, located at Konchi-in of the Nanzen-ji Temple, which was a lodge for Suden Choro, a priest who was a close advisor of the shogun.He also worked on the Hall of Huki (rich and noble), located on the hojo (abbot's chamber side) of the Gokito-den (Hall for Prayer), the tea house and garden and the Hojo garden of the honbo (priests' main living quarters) of this temple.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました

sen.j: 彼の書状の文面から推察できる様に、彼は江戸にある幕府からの愛顧を気にしていた関係から、公儀の作事（幕府の対皇室政策）以外は公家への出入りは極力避けていた。
sen.e: As we can surmise from the text of this letter, because he avoided to have relationship with nobles as much as possible other than sakuji (construction work) of the shogunate (policy of the bakufu toward the imperial family, because he was nervous about patronage by the bakufu in Edo.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外措置
sen.e: As we can surmise from his letters, he was nervous about his patronage from the shogunate in Edo, and went to great lengths to avoid getting involved with noble familes in any capacity other than in his role in shoguate construction.
sen.cmt: Natural English
sen.e: As we can surmise from his letters, he was nervous about his patronage from the shogunate in Edo, and went to great lengths to avoid getting involved with noble families in any capacity other than in his role in shoguate construction.
sen.cmt: スペル

sen.j: 師古田重然のような非業の死を避けるためとも思われる。
sen.e: It is surmised that it was for the purpose of avoiding unnatural death similar to that for his teacher, Shigenari FURUTA.
It is possible that he was being careful in order to avoid the unnatural death which had befallen his teacher, Shigenari FURUTA.
sen.cmt: Natural English
sen.e: It is possible that he was being careful in order to avoid the unnatural death which had befallen his teacher, Shigenari FURUTA.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 彼が奉行として参画したと思われる遺構は、建築としては妙心寺麟祥院の春日のつぼね霊屋（慶長年間、うち溜りを移建）、氷室神社拝殿（慶長年間、内裏池亭を移建）、大覚寺宸殿（慶長年間の内裏の元和期増造の際に中宮宸殿となる）、金地院東照宮、同茶室、同方丈南庭（鶴亀庭）、南禅寺本坊方丈南庭、大徳寺竜光院密庵席（みったんせき）、孤篷庵表門前の石橋、同前庭、同忘筌席露地（建築は寛政年間に焼失後、旧様式を踏襲して復元された）、仙洞御所南池庭のいで島およびその東護岸の石積み部分などである。
sen.e: Structural remnants which we believe he was involved in are, as construction, are the tamaya (a mausoleum) for Kasuga no Tsubone (in Keicho era (1596 - 1615, partly, the waiting room was relocated.), haiden (a hall of worship) of the Himuro-jinja Shrine (in Keicho era (1596 - 1615), dairi chitei [内裏池亭 読み,英語表記とも不明] was relocated.), Shinden of the Daikaku-ji Temple (changed to Chugu Shinden on the occasion of expansion in Genna era (1615 - 1617) of the dairi (Imperial Palace) constructed in Keicho era), Tosho-gu of the Konchi-in, tea house of the same, south garden of the hojo (an abbot's chamber) of the same (Tsuru-Kame garden (literally, crane- turtle garden)), south garden of hojo of the honbo of the Nanzen-ji Temple, Mittanseki of Ryukoin of the Daitoku-ji Temple, stone bridge in front of the front gate of Kohoan, a front garden of the same, Bosenseki Roji of the same (the building was lost by fire in the Kansei era (1789 - 1800), and restored after the original style), island [いで島 定訳不明] of the south pond garden [仙洞御所南池庭 定訳不明] and the stone-lined part of the eastern bank protection.

Work to which he is believed to have contributed includes: the tamaya (mausoleum) for Kasuga no Tsubone (in Keicho era (1596 - 1615, specifically relocation of waiting room); the haiden (hall of worship) of the Himuro-jinja Shrine (Keicho era (1596 - 1615), relocation of Dairi Chitei [内裏池亭 読み,英語表記とも不明]); Shinden of the Daikaku-ji Temple (became Chugu Shinden in the Genna era (1615 - 1617) upon the expansion of the dairi (Imperial Palace) first constructed in the Keicho era); Toshogu (Priest house), tea house and south garden (Tsuru-Kame garden (literally, crane- turtle garden)) of hojo (abbot's chamber) of Konchi-in; south garden of hojo of the honbo (priests main living quarters) of the Nanzen-ji Temple; Mittanseki (tea house) of Ryukoin of Daitoku-ji Temple; stone bridge in front of the front gate of Kohoan, a front garden and Bosenseki Roji of the same (building was lost to fire in the Kansei era (1789 - 1800) and restored in the original style); and the islands and stone-lined eastern shore of the south garden of Sento Gosho.
sen.cmt: Added semi-colons for more clarity.
sen.e: Work to which he is believed to have contributed include: the tamaya (mausoleum) for Kasuga no Tsubone (during the Keicho era (1596 - 1615), relocation of the waiting room); the haiden (hall of worship) of the Himuro-jinja Shrine (Keicho era (1596 - 1615), relocation of Dairi Chitei (an arbor by a pond of the Imperial Palace)); Shinden of the Daikaku-ji Temple (became Chugu Shinden in the Genna era (1615 - 1617) upon the expansion of the dairi (Imperial Palace) first constructed in the Keicho era); Toshogu (Priest house), tea house and south garden (Tsuru-Kame garden (literally, crane-turtle garden)) of hojo (abbot's chamber) of Konchi-in; south garden of hojo of the honbo (priests main living quarters) of the Nanzen-ji Temple; Mittanseki (tea house) of Ryukoin of Daitoku-ji Temple; stone bridge in front of the front gate of Kohoan, a front garden and Bosenseki Roji of the same (building was lost to fire in the Kansei era (1789 - 1800) and restored in the original style); and the islands and stone-lined eastern shore of the south garden of Sento Gosho.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました

sen.j: また、加賀国大聖寺藩長流亭も手がけていると言われている。
sen.e: It is told that he also built Choryutei in Daishoji Domain in Kaga Province.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外措置
sen.e: He is also said to have built Choryutei in Daishoji Domain in Kaga Province.
sen.cmt: Natural English
sen.e: He is also said to have built Choryutei in Daishoji Domain in Kaga Province.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 幼年期から時折のぞかせた天才的素質を先輩たちは嘱望し、自らも精進することにより、その晩年にいたってますます冴えを見せた。
sen.e: His seniors put their hopes on gifted genius which he showed sometimes since his childhood, and, by trying hard by himself, he sophisticated his genius in his later days.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外措置
sen.e: His seniors had high hopes based on the flashes of genius he showed as a youth, and, thanks to his efforts to improve himself, he was to show even great brilliance in later life..
sen.cmt: Natural English
sen.e: His seniors had high hopes based on the flashes of genius he showed as a youth and together with his efforts to improve himself, he was to show even greater brilliance in later life.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました

sen.j: 庭園の作風については、遠州は師である古田織部の作風を受け継ぎ発展させたとされるが、遠州の著しい特徴は庭園に直線を導入したことである。
sen.e: With respect to the style of gardens, it is told that Enshu succeeded the style of his teacher, Oribe FUKUTA and further developed it, but remarkable feature of Enshu is introduction of direct line in the garden.
In his gardens Enshu carried on and developed the style of his teacher, Oribe FUKATA, but what marks him out is the introduction of the straight line to his gardens.
sen.cmt: Natural English
sen.e: In his gardens, Enshu carried on and developed the style of his teacher, Oribe FURUTA, but Enshu's significant contribution to gardening is the introduction of straight lines.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました

sen.j: 屏風画に残る御所で実施した築地の庭（後には改修される）や桂離宮の輿寄の「真の飛石」が小堀好みと伝えられた所以とされる。
sen.e: It is told to be the reason why Tsuiji no niwa (garden with a roofed mud-wall) implemented in the gosho (Imperial Palace)(improved later) recorded in a folding screen painting and "Shin no tobiishi (stepping-stone)" in okoshiyose [定訳不明] of Katsura Imperial Villa are said to be Kobori-style.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外措置
sen.e: It is for their inclusion or straight lines that the Tsuiji no niwa (garden with a roofed mud-wall) in Gosho (Imperial Palace)(altered later) shown in a folding screen painting the the "Shin no tobiishi (stepping-stones)" in Okoshiyose (Rest house) [定訳不明] in Katsura Imperial Villa are are said to be in the Kobori style.
sen.cmt: It is not clear what "it" refers to in trans1
sen.e: Tsukiji no niwa (garden with a roofed mud-wall) in Gosho (Imperial Palace) (altered later) that can be still seen in an existing folding screen painting and the 'Shin no tobiishi (stepping-stones)' of the Koshiyose (palanquin porch) at Katsura Imperial Villa are said to be favorites of Kobori.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました

sen.j: 種々な形の切石を組み合わせた大きな畳石と正方形の切石を配置した空間構成は、以前には見られないものである。
sen.e: The space composition in which large tatamiishi [畳石 定訳不明] of combined hewn stones in different shapes and square hewn stones are arranged is not seen before.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外措置
sen.e: A spatial arrangement having different-shaped stones grouped to form large "tatami ishi" (paving stones) and square-hewn stones had never beeen seen before.
sen.cmt: I think "tatami ishi" can be translated as "paving stones".
sen.e: Spatial arrangement of combining different-shaped stones of large paving stones and square-hewn stones had never been seen before.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました

sen.j: 直線に使った長い畳石は桂離宮内の諸所にも見られるが、特に松琴亭前の反りのない石橋は圧巻である。
sen.e: Long tatamiishi used in a direct line can be seen in various places in Katsura Imperial Villa, but, in particular, a stone bridge without warpage in front of Shokintei (a building for tea ceremony) is a masterpiece.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外措置
sen.e: Long paving stones arranged in straight lines can be seen in various places in Katsura Imperial Villa, but the finest example is the archless stone bridge in front of Shokintei (building for tea ceremony).
sen.cmt: Natural English
sen.e: Long paving stones arranged in straight lines can be seen in various places in Katsura Imperial Villa, but the archless stone bridge in front of Shokintei (building for tea ceremony) is especially magnificient.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました

sen.j: また、樹木を大胆に刈り込み、花壇を多く用い、芝生の庭園を作るなどの工夫は、西洋の影響が指摘される。
sen.e: The influence of the Western technique is pointed out for arrangement to prune trees without hesitation, using many flowerbeds and creating a garden with lawn.
Moreover, techniques such as the adventurous pruning of the trees, the frequent use of flowerbeds and the creation of lawns point to Western influence.
sen.cmt: Natural English
sen.e: Moreover, techniques such as adventurous pruning of the trees, frequent use of flowerbeds and creation of grass lawns point to a western influence.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました

sen.j: 遠州の茶の湯は現在ではきれいさびと称され、遠州流・小堀遠州流として続いている。
sen.e: Enshu's chanoyu is currently called kirei sabi [定訳不明] and it has been inherited as Enshuryu or Kobori Enshuryu.
Enshu tea ceromony is currently called Kirei sabi [定訳不明] and continues to be passed down in the Enshu/Kobori Enshu tradition.
sen.cmt: Natural English
sen.e: Enshu's style of tea ceremony is currently now called Kirei sabi [定訳不明] and continues to be passed down as the Enshu/Kobori Enshu school.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました

sen.j: 遠州は和歌や藤原定家の書を学び、王朝文化の美意識を茶の湯に取り入れた。
sen.e: Enshu learned waka poems and handwriting of FUJIWARA no Sadaie and adopted the sense of beauty (an aesthetic sense) of cultures of the dynasty age into chanoyu.
Enshu studied the waka poems and handwriting of FUJIWARA no Sadaie and introduced the aesthetics of the Heian period into tea ceremony.
sen.cmt: According to http://dic.yahoo.co.jp, 王朝 is 武家時代に対して、天皇親政の時代。奈良・平安時代をさし、特に平安時代をいうこともある。
sen.e: Enshu studied the waka poems and handwriting of FUJIWARA no Sadaie and introduced the aesthetics of the Heian period into the tea ceremony.
sen.cmt: FBでは△になっているが、どこが修正されたのか不明。文字化け＃部分の修正のみと思われます。

sen.j: 彼の選定した茶道具は和歌から取った銘がつけられ、後世中興名物と呼ばれる。
sen.e: Tea utensils selected by him are given names taken from waka poets and later called chuko meibutsu [定訳不明].
Tea utensils he selected were taken from waka poems and later came to be known as chuko meibutsu [定訳不明].
sen.cmt: Natural English
sen.e: Tea utensils he selected were given names from waka poems and later became known as chuko meibutsu [定訳不明].
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました

sen.j: 茶室は織部のものより窓を増やし明るくした。
sen.e: He increased the number of windows in the tea house compared with those of ORIBE, and made the inside lighter.
In tea houses, he increased the number of windows compared with the designs of ORIBE and made the inside lighter.
sen.cmt: Natural English
sen.e: The tea houses he designed had more windows and were brighter inside than those of Oribe.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました

sen.j: 彼の門下としては松花堂昭乗、沢庵宗彭が有名。
sen.e: As his pupils, Shojo SHOKADO and Takuan Soho are famous.
Among his pupils, Shojo SHOKADO and Takuan Soho are famous.
sen.cmt: Natural English
sen.e: Shojo SHOKADO and Takuan Soho are famous among his pupils.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました

sen.j: 遠州がもたらした美意識を華道世界に反映させた流儀として江戸後期に特に栄えた。
sen.e: It flourished in the latter half of the Edo Period as a school that reflect the sense of beauty brought by Enshu to the world of flower arrangement.
Flower arrangement flourished in the latter part of the Edo Period in a style that that reflected the aethestics introduced to the field by Enshu.
sen.cmt: It is not clear what "it" is referring to in trans1.
sen.e: A style of flower arrangement that reflected the aesthetics introduced to the field by Enshu was especially popular during the late Edo period.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました

sen.j: 遠州の茶の流れを汲む春秋軒一葉が挿花として天地人の三才を確立し、茶の花から独自の花形へと展開していった。
sen.e: Shunjuken Ichiyo, who was affiliated with Enshu's tea ceremony, established the three powers of "heaven, earth and human" in flower arrangement and developed cha no hana (flower arrangement for tea ceremony into a unique form of flowers.

Shunjuken Ichiyo, who was affiliated with the Enshu style of tea ceremony, established the idea of the three powers of "heaven, earth and human" in flower arrangement and developed cha no hana (flower arrangement for tea ceremony) into an independent style.
sen.cmt: Natural English
sen.e: Shunjuken Ichiyo, who was affiliated with the Enshu style of the tea ceremony, established the idea of the three powers of heaven, earth and human in flower arrangement and developed an independent style from cha no hana (flower arrangement for tea ceremony).
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました

sen.j: 正風、日本橋、浅草の三大流派でほぼ規矩が確立した。
sen.e: The majority of standard practices in flower arrangment were established in three schools of Shofu, Nihonbashi and Asakusa.
The majority of standard practices in flower arrangment were established in three schools of Shofu, Nihonbashi and Asakusa.
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: The majority of standard practices in flower arrangement were established by the three main schools, Shofu, Nihonbashi and Asakusa.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました

sen.j: やがて江戸末期から昭和初期にかけて、既存の流派から独立する家元・宗家が多数生まれ、遠州の名がつく流派が明治期をピークにかなり増える。
sen.e: From the end of the Edo Period to the beginning of the Showa era, many iemoto (the head family of a school) and soke (the head family or house) were born gaining independence from existing schools, and the number of schools having Enshu in its name increased having its peak in the Meiji era.

From the end of the Edo Period to the beginning of the Showa era, many iemoto (the head family of a school) and soke (the head family or house) independent from existing schools came into existence, and the number of schools having Enshu in their name increased, reaching a peak in the Meiji era.
sen.cmt: Natural English
sen.e: From the end of the Edo Period to early Showa Period, many iemoto (head of a school) and soke (head of a house) gained independence from existing schools and the number of schools having Enshu in their name increased, reaching a peak during the Meiji era.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました

sen.j: 総じて花枝に曲をかなり大げさにつける手法がある。
sen.e: Generally speaking, these schools use techniques to introduce exaggerated curves to branches and stems of flowers.
Generally speaking, these schools use techniques to introduce exaggerated curves to branches and stems of flowers.

In flower arrangment, kyokuike (the introduction of curves) is said to be a difficult technique to learn.

sen.j: 八条宮智仁親王、近衛信尋、木下勝俊など当代一流の文化人たちとの交際が知られる。
sen.e: His friendship with the top men of culture at that time such as Imperial Prince Hachijonomiya Toshihito, Nobuhiro KONOE and Katsutoshi KINOSHITA is known.
Enshu is known to have had friendships some of the most cultured men of his gneration, including Imperial Prince Hachijonomiya Toshihito, Nobuhiro KONOE and Katsutoshi KINOSHITA.

sen.j: 元和7年（1621年）と寛永19年（1642年）の江戸から上洛途次の歌入日記にもその文学趣味がよく現れている。
sen.e: His taste for literature is well shown in his diaries with poems for his trips from Edo to Kyoto in 1621 and 1642.
His interest in literature is clearly shown in his diaries which contain poems for his trips from Edo to Kyoto in 1621 and 1642.

sen.j: 遠州が着用したと伝えられる当世具足が東京国立博物館に所蔵されている。
sen.e: A tosei-gusoku (a type of armor) which is told Enshu wore is possessed by the Tokyo National Museum.
A tosei-gusoku (a type of armor) said to have been worn by Enshu is in the collection of Tokyo National Museum.
